results.abstract: B Faries of The Washington Star repts that Apollo 15 astronauts Col Scott, Col Irwin and Lt Col Worden smuggled 400 envelopes bearing US space mission commem stamps, astronauts' signatures, Apollo 15 emblem and notarized certification of their presence on flight to moon aboard spacecraft in July '71 and then sold 100 of them; German air post dealer H E Sieger negotiated deal, amounting to $150,350; chief astronaut Slayton says Apollo crew did not profit from venture; illus of Apollo 15 covers
results.snippet: PERSONAL preference kits of the crew of Apollo 15 which landed on the moon July 30, 1971, contained, among other memorabilia for themselves and friends, 400 envelopes bearing U.S. stamps commemorating American space missions -- in addition to the...
results.lead_paragraph: PERSONAL preference kits of the crew of Apollo 15 which landed on the moon July 30, 1971, contained, among other memorabilia for themselves and friends, 400 envelopes bearing U.S. stamps commemorating American space missions -- in addition to the special cover of the U.S. Postal Service that the flight commander, David B. Scott, canceled before millions of television viewers on Aug. 2, 1971.

results.abstract: US NASA reprimands Apollo 15 astronauts Col Scott, Col Irwin and Lt Col Worden for smuggling 632 specially stamped and canceled envelopes aboard spacecraft to moon in July '71 and later selling 100 of them in exchange for trust fund to be established for their children; contends that astronauts decided to cancel deal after envelopes' existence on collectors market was already publicized, and made no profit; NASA Deputy Admr Low says that although astronauts were under much stress before flight, their actions directly violate NASA regulations and cannot be condoned; of 632 stamped envelopes or 'covers,' 238 were authorized and only 1, which is now on display in Brussels, was actually canceled on moon with official sanction of NASA; 100 were sold by German dealers H Eiermann and H E Sieger for $1,500 each; 60 of authorized covers and 300 of unauthorized have been impounded; Scott, Irwin and Worden pors; illus of covers

headline.main: Apollo 15 Crew Is Reprimanded; Apollo 15 Astronauts Are Reprimanded

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts were reprimanded today by the space agency for smuggling 400 specially stamped and canceled envelopes to the moon and back last July. Later 100 of these were sold by a German stamp dealer for a sum...

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Apollo 15 astronauts were reprimanded today by the space agency for smuggling 400 specially stamped and canceled envelopes to the moon and back last July. Later 100 of these were sold by a German stamp dealer for a sum reported to be more than $150,000.

results.abstract: NASA announces on July 12 that Lt Col Worden will be reassigned from astronaut corps to another position in agency, but notes that reassignment was originally made before Apollo 15 astronauts were reprimanded for stamp-smuggling incident; NASA spokesman J P Donnelly comments on possible elimination of 'personal preference kit' astronauts have previously been allowed to take aboard space flights; Worden biog details noted

headline.main: Col. Worden to Be Reassigned From Post in Astronaut Corps

results.snippet: HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI) -Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden of the Air Force, reprimanded yesterday for permitting the sale of unauthorized stamped and concealed envelopes that he and two other astronauts took to the moon last July on the Apollo 15 mission,...
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 12 (UPI) -Lieut. Col. Alfred M. Worden of the Air Force, reprimanded yesterday for permitting the sale of unauthorized stamped and concealed envelopes that he and two other astronauts took to the moon last July on the Apollo 15 mission, will be reassigned from the astronaut corps to another position with the space agency, NASA announced today.

results.abstract: Singer G Harrison is fined equivalent of $50 and found guilty of careless driving at hearing in Maidenhead, GB; admits he recently was traveling at 65 to 70 mph when his car crashed into hwy barrier

headline.main: A Message for the High Court

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: REVIEWS AND OTHER DATA ON SPECIFIC PRODUCTIONS

results.snippet: People usually sue first and, if disappointed, carry their case to the Supreme Court. Maryann Clifford is different. Miss Clifford, who plans to enter law school this autumn, went to the United States Supreme Court first, seeking one of the summer...
results.lead_paragraph: People usually sue first and, if disappointed, carry their case to the Supreme Court. Maryann Clifford is different. Miss Clifford, who plans to enter law school this autumn, went to the United States Supreme Court first, seeking one of the summer messenger jobs customarily made available to law students.

results.abstract: Drs P K Chapman and A W England resign from US astronaut corps, July 15; Chapman will become principal research scientist at Avco Everett Research Lab

headline.main: 2 Scientists Resign Posts In the Astronaut Program

results.snippet: HOUSTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Drs. Philip K. Chapman and Anthony W. England have resigned from the astronaut corps.
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Drs. Philip K. Chapman and Anthony W. England have resigned from the astronaut corps.

results.abstract: article reviewing Apollo 15 stamp smuggling episode holds that 'most astonishing aspect' is highly respectable background and character of 3 astronauts involved

headline.main: Editorial Article 1 -- No Title; Astronauts: Say It Ain't So, Dave'

results.snippet: It was just three years ago today that the Apollo 11 astronauts blasted off on man's first trip to the surface of the moon -- and hardly had they returned from that noble journey when the first rumors began. The wife of a lunar scientist at the...
results.lead_paragraph: It was just three years ago today that the Apollo 11 astronauts blasted off on man's first trip to the surface of the moon -- and hardly had they returned from that noble journey when the first rumors began. The wife of a lunar scientist at the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston, so the story went, had been reported seen wearing an unusual ring with a small gray rock in a solitaire setting.

results.abstract: Former analyst in US Natl Security Agency, in article in Ramparts magazine, repts US has refined its electronics intelligence techniques to point where it can break Soviet codes, listen to and understand Soviet communications and coding systems, and keep track of virtually every Soviet jet plane or missile-carrying submarine around world; uses pseudonym W Peck in article (but later identifies himself as P Fellwock); also discusses his revelations in an int with NY Times; highlights of disclosures include data gathering on USSR activities in astronautics, on '67 Arab-Israeli war and Vietnam war; says he makes disclosures because of his opposition to Vietnam war; experts in Washington corroborate many of his disclosures but strongly deny US has broken sophisticated codes of USSR or any other nations; code expert D Kahn quoted; neither Natl Security Agency nor CIA will comment; illus of agency emblem

headline.main: Ability to Break Soviet Codes Reported; U.S. Reportedly Able to Break All of the Soviet's Codes

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The United States is reported to have refined its electronics intelligence techniques to the point where it can break Soviet codes, listen to and understand Soviet communications and coding systems and keep track of virtually...

byline.original: By BENJAMIN WELLESSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The United States is reported to have refined its electronics intelligence techniques to the point where it can break Soviet codes, listen to and understand Soviet communications and coding systems and keep track of virtually every Soviet jet piane or missile-carrying submarine around the world.

results.abstract: results of 10-day meeting between US and USSR space officials at NASA Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston are released on July 17; target date for joint space mission is July '75, but exact date is uncertain; Soviet Soyuz will be launched 1st as safety measure, as it must be lifted over land and has less freedom to maneuver than Apollo, which will have launch trajectory over sea; Apollo could be launched 7 1/2, 31 or 54 1/2 hrs after Soyuz to make successful rendezvous in space about 24 hrs later; ships will remain linked in orbit for about 48 hrs, during which time 2 Amer crewmen will visit Soyuz on 1st day and 1 Soviet crewman will visit Apollo on 2d day; transferral between differing atmospheres of 2 spacecraft requires 2 hrs in air lock, preventing more than 3 men from participating in exchange; crewmen for flight will not be named until July '73 and scientific experiments to be performed during flight are not yet determined; 22-member Russian delegation was led by Soviet Intercosmos Council chmn B N Petrov and USSR project dir K D Bushuyev, who are scheduled to leave US on July 18; Amer officials at meeting were Manned Spacecraft Center dir C C Kraft and US project dir G S Lunney; Russians note growing friendliness between nations and say greatest problem facing project is 'compatibility' of 2 spacecraft; illus of 4 officials with models of their respective craft

headline.main: Details Disclosed on U.S.-Soviet Space Link-Up in 1975; Apollo and Soyuz to Dock for 2 Days in the Earth's Orbit

results.snippet: HOUSTON, July 17 -- Soviet and American space officials disclosed here today some details of the first joint space flight by men from their two countries, involving a two-day link-up of two spacecraft in earth orbit in 1975.

byline.original: By WILLIAM K. STEVENSSpecial to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 17 -- Soviet and American space officials disclosed here today some details of the first joint space flight by men from their two countries, involving a two-day link-up of two spacecraft in earth orbit in 1975.

results.abstract: Apollo 15 astronaut Irwin says that remaining stamp covers taken to moon which are being held by NASA will be sold when released to create educ fund for 3 astronauts' children

headline.main: NASA CONCERNED OVER MOON STATUE; Copies of Memorial Being Sold for $750 Each

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An official of the space agency deplored today the commercial exploitation of a memorial sculpture placed on the moon last summer by the crew of Apollo 15. Copies of the small cast-aluminum figure have been placed on sale at...

byline.original: By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 21 -- An official of the space agency deplored today the commercial exploitation of a memorial sculpture placed on the moon last summer by the crew of Apollo 15. Copies of the small cast-aluminum figure have been placed on sale at $750 apiece.

results.abstract: Apollo 15 astronaut Col Scott is dropped from US astronaut corps and assigned job of tech asst to Apollo program; NASA spokesman J Riley says stamp smuggling incident was 'one of the considerations' in decision; Scott's retirement drops number of active astronauts to 39; retirement of Col Irwin and Lt Col Worden noted

headline.main: Scott Dropped as an Astronaut; Stamp Affair a 'Consideration'

results.snippet: HOUSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Col. David R. Scott of the Air Force, commander of Apollo 15 and one of three astronauts recently reprimanded for smuggling 400 stamp covers to the moon and back, has been dropped from the astronaut corps and given a space...
results.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON, July 26 (AP) -- Col. David R. Scott of the Air Force, commander of Apollo 15 and one of three astronauts recently reprimanded for smuggling 400 stamp covers to the moon and back, has been dropped from the astronaut corps and given a space agency desk job.

headline.main: Monies and Medals in New Exhibit

results.lead_paragraph: MORE than 500 guests, including Government officials and prominent numismatists, attended the recent dedication of the new Exhibits Hall of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington.

results.abstract: Apollo 14 astronauts Capts Shepard and Mitchell and Lt Col Roosa carried 200 silver medals coined by Franklin Mint in Philadelphia aboard Jan '71 flight to moon; astronauts retained 150 for their private use and others were either stored in mint vault or distributed to subscribers as gifts, but no remuneration was involved

headline.main: Apollo 14 Crew Carried Medals Coined by a Private Mint on Trip; Crew of Apollo 14 Took Medals on Flight to the Moon

results.snippet: WASHINGTON, July 30 -The Apollo 14 astronauts, without the knowledge of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, carried 200 silver medals coined by a private mint on their moon flight in January, 1971.

byline.original: Special to The New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 30 -The Apollo 14 astronauts, without the knowledge of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, carried 200 silver medals coined by a private mint on their moon flight in January, 1971.
